text:

Simply forward this email, or share this link: <http://inst.cr/t/ixNDdj>
<@U027PV4AP>: have you used instacart?
we use it now for costco delivery and it's awesome!
super easy
awesome
<@U02613K0X> yes, it is people
interesting article on soylent: <http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/05/12/the-end-of-food>

attachments.title: The End of Food - The New Yorker
attachments.text: In December of 2012, three young men were living in a claustrophobic apartment in San Francisco’s Tenderloin district, working on a technology startup. They had received a hundred and seventy thousand dollars from the incubator Y Combinator, but their project—a plan to make inexpensive cell-phone towers—had failed. Down to their last seventy thousand dollars, they resolved to keep trying out new software ideas until they ran out of money. But how to make the funds last? Rent was a sunk cost. Since they were working frantically, they already had no social life. As they examined their budget, one big problem remained: food.
attachments.fallback: The New Yorker: The End of Food - The New Yorker

text: and now people can be soylent too!

from that article: "Rhinehart says that, in fact, he took the name Soylent from the science-fiction novel that inspired “Soylent Green”—“Make Room! Make Room!” (1966), in which a combination of soybeans and lentils becomes a solution to the depredations of overpopulation."

It's funny to me that a man at one point "living mostly on ramen, corn dogs, and Costco frozen quesadillas—supplemented by Vitamin C tablets, to stave off scurvy" would be one to invent a nutritional panacea.
even einstein had to learn basic math
it was meant as a cheap nutritional solution so he wouldnt be stuck eating frozen quesadillas, which was all he could afford.
i think its brilliant, but i think its silly that there are people trying to only live on soylent.
because food is awesome

Buying tortillas and cheese at Costco is probably more economical than buying frozen quesadillas, but I might be wrong. It's surprising that some people find eating so much of a nuisance that they're excited to have this workaround.
After all, food is just fuel, right?
It think people overdo it on both extremes. There's the foodies and the pragmatics. All valid depending your point of view.

Food is awesome. And I think the replacement of actual food  for the sake of efficiency concept is the one weird part to me. I think food is more than just fuel. The cultural and communal significance is also important. I don't think the thing is totally terrible, just weird that it's trying to solve an "inefficiency" problem.
It also depends on what you do for a living. When I was a TA/teacher/tutor many of my students were people who only had 15 mins to eat in their cars before they went to the next class or work.
I definitely don't intend to eat only Soylent. No way I can give up pizza, or tacos
I think we're fortunate that we get to eat good stuff every day and have the free time (and $) to wait for a Bunk sandwich to be made. Some people aren't that lucky.
somebody commented that they hoped Soylent would adopt a Tom's-like model, where they'd donate a bag to developing countries for every bag sold
that's a neat concept, but Tom's shoes are pretty expensive because of it
Seconding Kat, I think the "buy one, give one" model is more feel-good than doing-actual-good...

<@U02618EV1>: I think what you highlighted is exactly the problem though. Eating is one of the most basic primal needs and experiences of being human. That it gets relegated to a 15 minute slot where you might be able to "fit it in" is a cultural problem that shows the enormously screwed up priorities we have assigned ourselves in this society.
It's like sending boxes of t-shirts to Africa. They don't need t-shirts, they need....jobs making t-shirts (or the like)
Full disclosure: I am passionately and vocally anti-Soylent. I also self identify as a foodie, so take my opinions as you please given that information.
<@U02F4147F> +1 on the culture comment.
It reminds me a lot of the liquid food used for feeding with a j-tube.
Some love from the Portland Biz Journal: <http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/real-estate-daily/2014/09/creative-firm-blooms-plans-to-hire-more-workers-in.html?ana=twt>

attachments.title: Creative firm blooms, plans to hire more workers in the Central Eastside - Portland Business Journal
attachments.text: Uncorked has doubled the size of its office and is hoping to open the space not only to new employees but also to other startups and freelancers that need a place to work.
attachments.fallback: Portland Business Journal: Creative firm blooms, plans to hire more workers in the Central Eastside - Portland Business Journal

text: :thumbsup:
Rad!
Nice!
"By late 2015, he expects the company to employ about 40 people between full time and freelancers." BOOM!
:grin:
